author: Anthony Clark Arend
title: My name is Alexander Hamilton
text: Professor and Senior Associate Dean, Walsh School of Foreign Service, Georgetown University. @GUPolitics Faculty Liaison 9 mins ago My name is Alexander Hamilton Alexander Hamilton In Federalist 78 , Alexander Hamilton observed : The complete independence of the courts of justice is peculiarly essential in a limited Constitution. By a limited Constitution, I understand one which contains certain specified exceptions to the legislative authority [and I can only suspect, Hamilton would include executive authority]; such, for instance, as that it shall pass no bills of attainder, no ex-post-facto laws, and the like. Limitations of this kind can be preserved in practice no other way than through the medium of courts of justice, whose duty it must be to declare all acts contrary to the manifest tenor of the Constitution void. Without this, all the reservations of particular rights or privileges would amount to nothing. And, of course, as Chief Justice John Marshall famously affirmed in Marbury v. Madison : It is emphatically the duty of the Judicial Department to say what the law is. So, “ What is our country coming to when a judge can halt a Homeland Security travel ban and anyone, even with bad intentions, can come into U.S.? . . .” A reaffirmation of the separation of powers, a bedrock of American Constitutional democracy.
